column4: hi, I'm looking for some solution to my problem. I'm using Ubuntu Dapper, it works fine, I'm happy. The only problem is that for my work I need dbus 0.62, and I don't know how in Ubuntu world I can solve it, since backports are only for security, and edgy (which has 0.62) is probably very unstable.
backports are not only for security. actually, backports are *not* for security, that's what dapper-security is for. only, backports haven't yet been activated anyway
you could probably try compiling the edgy package, but no guarantees
does it mean that I can wait for backports to eventually backport to dapper? or would it be smarter to get edgy package and try to install it and cross fingers?

backports only happen if you ask for them, and even then, i'm afraid something like dbus wouldn't get backported, as a lot of things, i believe, depend on it -- backports is mostly for "stand-alone" packages
don't just get the edgy package anyway - get the *source* package and compile it, that ought to be sort of safer. still do cross your fingers though
thnx :)
./configure --prefix=/usr will be enough?
uh, leave configure alone and just use the apt system to compile... "apt-get -b source packagename", after doing "sudo apt-get build-dep packagename". that should give you a binary package
ouch, depenencies will kill me here :(
is it worth trying to compile it on my own if using apt-get -b sources returned tons of required dependencies, but ./configure was happy with what it found?
not necessarily. perhaps some dependencies are not strictly necessary to compile, but are still needed to enable all the features ubuntu needs. let me have a look
hm well, i think to be on the safe side you really should install anything that "apt-get build-dep dbus" wants you to instal.
103 mb update, almost all core packages ;) I think I'll give up
well try the binary package from edgy then
if it has dependencies, they need to be satisfied - no easy way around that.
but it's update from 0.60 to 0.62, no ABI/API changes, it shouldn't have dependency change :(
well, let me see
the only real thing it adds beside of few bug fixes is QT bindings which are needed for me :(
well apparently it needs libc6 2.4 rather than 2.3. that looks like quite a strong requirement
where did you find it? So why ./configure is happy on my machine (Dapper?)
i'm talking about the *binary* package dependencies
oh, ok.
I'll try with selfcompiling sources *^^*
